title: Combining a co-occurrence-based and a semantic measure for entity linking

author: Besnik Fetahu, L3S Research Center, Leibniz University of Hannover

segmentation: Hi everyone, my name is Bethany care and I'm going to present some work that we've conducted together with the Pokhriyal University in Brazil.
So it's about entity linking and we're going.
We did something.
A combined approach that relies on some semantic measures and as well as Co occurrence measures so.
First, an outline of the of this talk today, so we're going to see the introduction.

Katz Index ND Co.
Occurrence based measure and then we will see based on some results analysis that actually the connections that these two techniques uncover are actually complementary.

So a natural choice is the combination of both and then the evaluation set up the data set the gold standard, and so on, and also the results that follow this evaluation and finally some conclusions and some future work.

And actually many of them are wrong.
So what we have to consider as well is that this is an exhaustive process considering the large amount of data.
And then therefore we need to consider also scalability as an issue in our proposed approaches.

They are quite quite related, but if you would use some information retrieval technique for measuring similarity, then here we would fail because they don't share common terminology and therefore it's very difficult to quantify them as a similar.
But if we look at the for example Charlotte Bobcats and the Carmelo Anthony entities, they are clearly related via the Entity Eastern Conference, which is part of the NBA.
So the Carmelo Anthony is related to the Eastern Conference because it belongs to the New York Knicks basketball teams, which is also part of the Eastern Conference.
So these two entities can be related in.
And therefore the resources that they belong to can be as well related and considered as similar.

And it follows some optimization factors where we want to avoid actually running into exponential problems, because if you consider the path link between two entities higher than greater than six, then the problem becomes exponential and we will also rely on the small world assumption where at some degree, then all the entities are connected and the way we determined for the path length of four was that.

Therefore increase as well as the coverage of detected links.
So the evaluation set up for four hour.
Experiments was that we use USA TODAY News.
We had 40,000 document pairs and 80,000 entity pairs.
We constructed the gold standard where we randomly picked 600 document pairs and thousand entity pairs and we generate the gold standard using crowdsourcing.
So basically human evaluators.

Basically on correctness unexpectedness.

Resources and how the two entities are connected and they have two choices from strongly disagree to strongly agree and also the expected Ness like when they see that there's actually exist the connection between entities, whether they expect that or not.

So to conclude, some of the findings and approaches in this sits in the entity linking is that we propose the combination of these two approaches which exploited the knowledge graphs from DB pedia and also utilize the information from the from the search engines and the we managed to make it scale the problem of finding entity links using the semantic connectivity score by finding.

The balanced tradeoff between the information gain and the processing time, and we kind of computed a gold standard which obviously needs lots of more work to train the users and as well to to show the information on how it became to the actually establishment of the link between two entities and the combination of the of the two approaches seemed to be the most viable approach, and it increased quite well the coverage of.
Detected entity links.
